awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Structured Matrix Computations: Foundations, Methods, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed research is concerned with innovative and systematic structured matrix computations. Large-scale matrices arise frequently in mathematical computations and engineering simulations. By exploiting the inherent structures, one can often develop new fast and reliable matrix methods. This work is especially interested in rank structures and data-sparse matrices, as well as innovative ideas of using them in the solutions of practical numerical problems (especially high dimensional discretized problems). The PI proposes to enhance both the flexibility and the applicability of structured methods. Systematic analysis for the structures and the methods will be included. The following aspects will be studied: (1) theoretical foundations of rank properties and new nested hierarchical structures; (2) new perspectives for exploring matrix structures, such as matrix-free structured sparse factorization, factorization update, and nested localization and sparsification; (3) efficient rank structured matrix algorithms, their analysis, and their use in fast solutions of large linear systems, least squares problems, eigenvalue problems, discretized PDEs, and numerous engineering applications.

Matrix computations lie at the heart of most scientific computation tasks. This research will systematically extend classical dense and sparse matrix computations to data-sparse ones, and will introduce new structured matrix theories and techniques into scientific and engineering computations. The project will result in practical ways to reveal and use structures, which will further yield fast and reliable algorithms such as stable direct three dimensional PDE solvers with nearly linear complexity. Understanding the structures will also provide new perspectives to classical challenges in numerical solutions, such as large fill-in, ill conditioning, lack of explicit matrices, and repeated solutions with highly varying parameters. The proposed algorithms can be used (say, as kernel solvers) in many complex numerical problems such as PDE solution, seismic imaging, signal processing, nanostructure modeling, and VLSI circuit simulation. The work will provide a multidisciplinary opportunity for researchers in different areas to participate. The project will result in freely available open source packages for practical applications, as well as courses ad tutorial and test materials for educational outreach programs that can stimulate the interest and achievement of students from diverse backgrounds.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, the PI and his students systematically studied innovative structured matrix computations, especially rank structured and data sparse matrix techniques. They performed theoretical studies for a broad range of numerical computations and showed the existence of rank structures and the feasibility of applying structured approximations. The approximation and numerical accuracies are rigorously shown, and it is verified that hierarchical rank structures not only improves the efficiency over classical matrix computations, but also enhances the stability by dramatically reducing the amount of error propagations. Backward stability estimates are provided for basic structured methods as well as advanced multi-layer ones. Rank structured methods have been systematically expanded to include not only fast direct linear solvers, but also least squares solvers, divide-and-conquer eigenvalue decompositions, iterative eigenvalue solvers, randomized and matrix-free structured solvers, effective and robust structured preconditioners, etc. Such studies give a comprehensive framework of advanced structured matrix computations that have both high efficiency and enhanced reliability.

In large numerical computations and practical applications, traditional matrix computations often encounter challenges such as dense fill-in, ill conditioning, poor stability, lack of explicit matrix data, etc. Structured matrix methods in this project provide a set of data-sparse strategies to overcome many of the challenges. Rank structured approximations often lead to reduced data storage and computational complexity by orders of magnitude. Computations on the structured data also lead to reduced error propagation. The structured methods are also very flexible in the sense that they can be made matrix-free (using matrix-vector multiplications only), and can serve as effective preconditioners. Such benefits are rigorously justified in this project, and make the methods in the project highly attractive for differential equation solution, optimization, seismic modeling, data analysis, signal processing, etc. Various test codes and tutorial materials were produced. The results were disseminated through presentations, publications, webpages, emails, etc. A data repository Structured Matrix Market was initialized to disseminate data from this project and the structured matrix data from the broader scientific community. The results have been used by many other researchers, groups, and students. Collaborations with researchers from different institutes and disciplines were established. Both graduate and undergraduate students were trained in multiple fields of mathematics and scientific computing. They were actively involved in both the research and the dissemination of the results. They also learned to write scientific papers, develop grant proposals, and give research presentations. Both the PI and the students actively participated in conferences and workshops by giving numerous presentations and co-organizing minisymposia and workshops. Two PhD students successfully defended their PhD thesis and started their new positions.
